title: Locating and licensing Chelmsford
content:
I'm trying to track down and license a font called Chelmsford. It's influenced by/derived/ripped-off from Optima, but comes in a very light weight and has a few added touches -- an Optima Titling Light, if you will. Check out the A, for example.

My guess is that this dates back to the early days of DTP, and is a digitization of someone's film/CRT version of Optima. MyFonts, Fontshop and Fonts.com (along with a general Google search) didn't turn up anything.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440im_/http:/typophile.com/files/chelmsford_3728.jpg)
author: marcox

comments.content:
This goes way back... before DTP. But the A is not something Zapf did, or I think would do.

Check ot Optima Nova. There you will get the weight you want and the author's true forms.

Michael

And the A is actually very ugly and ill fitting with the rest of the font. Too heavy, stilted to the right and has few weight consistencies with the other letters.

Probably Compugraphic or VGC.

Michael

This was an old AM (Addressograph-Multigraph) font from the seventies. Seems like I saw a digital version of it years ago, but I don't recall when or where. The "Q" is arbitrarily different, too, and can still be seen on Minnesota-based QUAST Trucking vehicles. I still wince a little when I see it.

In addition to Michael’s comment, a few links: [Optima Nova](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Optima%20Nova) offers a [Light weight](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.linotype.com/54144/optimanovalight-font.html) aswell as a [Titling version](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.linotype.com/54345/optimanovatitling-font.html) (an all-caps font with a couple of ligatures and alternates).

If you’re looking for a lighter titling version of Optima, check out [Young Finesse](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/doyaldyoung.com/113_YF_Roman/1131_Spec_YF_Roman/1131_Spec_YF_Roman.html) by [Doyald Young](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Doyald%20Young). That typeface started out as Fino Titling Light and is described by its author as “an ultra-thin, elegant drawing of Zapf’s Optima”.

Beorcana by [Carl Crossgrove](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Carl%20Crossgrove) has a wide range of [Display weights](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.beorcana.com/specs2.html).

If it may be less calligraphic, have a look at [Viceroy](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.typecuts.com/fonts.php?kid=8) by [Andrea Tinnes](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Andrea%20Tinnes) and [Verena Gerlach](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Verena%20Gerlach) which should be available soon: “ReVerb holds an exclusive license till June 2009” [!]  
Furthermore: [Accent Graphic](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=GTT0000001#characters) by [Nick Cooke](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Nick%20Cooke) has a Light, [TF Arrow](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.treacyfaces.com/050806_TFArrow_2c5a.html) by [Joseph Treacy](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Joseph%20Treacy) even comes with an Extralight.  
F

Thanks for the info, guys. Like many of the supplicants on this board, I'm dealing with a font specified by a 3rd party.

I've proposed Optima Nova Light as a substitute.

Marcox,

Did you ever find Chelmsford in a digitized format? I try downloading a font called OKLAHOMA, and I believe I'm getting Chelmsford, possibly, instead. Or there is some conflict with this OKLAHOMA font and some font which is or is similar to Chelmsford (it could even be Optima). I remember Chelmsford, and how much it looked like Optima, when I owned & lease some AM Varityper equipment (I got screwed out of a lot of money by that company) back in the eighties - may they NOT rest in peace).

I ended up licensing Optima Nova (the "remastered" version of Optima from Linotype) -- more weights, better drawn, etc.

[http://www.linotype.com/en/54142/Optimanova-family.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20120717144440/http:/www.linotype.com/en/54142/Optimanova-family.html "http://www.linotype.com/en/54142/Optimanova-family.html")
Good for you... So sorry about your arm and leg, as I know you paid dearly :-) But so did I!
I'm fortunate enough to work for a company that considers licensing type to be a routine cost of business. Optima Nova was for a magazine which redesigned in 2009, so we've gotten 3 years out of it.
Do you get to use the Titling set often? Isn't it lovely?
The titling initials are lovely, but they don't really fit the aesthetic of the publication. I just gaze at them longingly from time to time...
